Now the second dangling topic from last post - what is an Automation Maintenance Engineer? In the burden of managing all of this, coding something new was never a priority. Yet, the worm ğŸ› of coding made me do funny things. A senior once told - â€œI understand you love coding, but donâ€™t write a new method on every opportunity.â€ . So, yes - that is what I did for more than 2 years - maintained some automation suites, triggered them, reran the failed ones and scratched my head trying to figure out if the failed test is because of an actual bug or just a â€œsporadicâ€ issue. I heard whispers of people - saying- oh Manual testing is end of career, you would not make far with it. So my only option out seemed via higher studies - and I failed there too. ğŸ˜­ . I have never been studious, so even if I had made it to an elite institution - I would still be a back-bench-er. Being focused is very important to make an optimized move. Also, if I was unable to learn or grow in the current position, I should have started applying elsewhere. While appearing for interviews, I could have understood the market requirements, prepared myself. . In that â€œconfused spaceâ€ - I thought everyone else is doing better. Once I started cutting out the unwanted information - I realized what I wanted. . â–¶ï¸ Secondly, people will tell you what they think is the best for you - but honestly - no one knows what is going to happen. So if you feel like, take risks. Do what you want to do. You are answerable to only yourself. . â–¶ï¸ Finally - my stint as â€œAutomation Maintenance Engineerâ€ was not all waste. I learnt handling frequent context switches, I learnt â€œnot breakingâ€ under pressure. And I would definitely say - I had great seniors at work. So I was never reprimanded for mistakes. I was still given more responsibilities - which helped me build the confidence in myself. . And special mention to my first manager - who has always been there to hear my childish blabbering, never being impatient. I still remember a very important thing he said - â€œEven if you do move to development, the testing will always be an additional skill. This, which is your bread and butter right now, will always give you that extra edgeâ€. I learnt from him, how to be a leader - not a â€œbossâ€. . post2.title: Small steps matter
post2.content: Hello ğŸ‘‹ğŸ¼ - I am back. I hope you have already read the prelude here ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¼ . How I moved to being a developer from a testerâ€¦ . If you havenâ€™t - well just go on reading this post - I am glad you are here and would respect your time - so no need to go back and read right now ğŸ™†ğŸ»â€â™€ï¸ . So - where was I .. Ah yes! How a QA engineer (tester)ğŸ”ğŸ with more than half a decade of experience moved to being a developer ğŸ‘©ğŸ»â€ğŸ’». Well, honestly - when I started as a manual tester - from day 1 (or probably the day I understood what my job requires) - I started requesting for a role change. . I, in no way want to demean the role, and slowly you will realize how much my previous role helps my current one. Only - I love absolute honesty and that is how I will present myself - my exact thoughts at each stage, my decisions, what I missed and what I grabbed. . . In large MNCs - there is mostly no process of determining who should be tagged :link: to which technology. In a batch of 1000 students :busts_in_silhouette: - no one has the time to judge your capabilities - and my fate landed me in a batch of Manual Testing. Initially people kept saying - this is great, it means quick onsite opportunities :airplane:- I really did not know what the role was and was thrilled at this suggestion. As soon as the training unfolded - I realized I did not want onsite at the cost of â€œno codingâ€. Terms like â€œautomationâ€, â€œwhite/black/gray boxâ€ were aboslutely new - and I knew all I had to work with was â€œDecoding requirements and wording testsâ€. I started slipping into hopelessness by the day. . . Guidance matters - and I had none. No one told me that it was okay to look for another job right then - so I continued. I kept on working at writing test cases in excel sheets, manually executing them, learning the domain and the most important of all - understanding requirements. Whenever there was an opportunity - I did not forget to highlight my aspirations - I knew movement to development was almost not possible but the closest I could move to code was being an â€œAutomation Engineerâ€. . . And I took up every opportunity of building something in-house - failing at almost every task - because I had No Guidance. I did not know what frameworks were, I did not know how to develop websites - it all looked so dreamy, magical and out of reach :sob:. When I was told to contribute in an Android :iphone: application that was being built in-house - I could not understand anything:dizzy_face: in the 2 days provided to learn, and faltered to deliver. I kept losing faith in myself - but today when I look back, the only thing that is visible is - the scenario was bound to fail. I cannot expect myself to create a production ready UX design in just 2 days of learning android development. And it is Okay. :purple_heart: Many times we fail some tests because the tests are wrong - you cannot expect a baby bird to fly in a day. :hatching_chick: . But I proved my mettle wherever possible. I never backed out on any added responsibilities - and delivered more than what was expected. One day, out of the blue, I got a message from a friend in a different team - that an automation training was being organized for a new batch of trainees. I decided to go out of my way and ask my manager to enroll me in the training. It was not an easy talk - it really took a lot of reasoning and a little bit of displeasure, topped with extra working hours - but I finally got what I wanted. 1 week of training, going to office early and working late to compensate for the work - all did help in one main thing - I got noticed. :raising_hand: . So as soon as my current project ended - after a long tenure (at least for me) of 1 year - I was presented with the role of an Automation engineer in another project. . What happened next you say? Stay tuned for the next chapter the upcoming week.. Till then.. Okka Bye ğŸ‘©ğŸ»â€ğŸ’» .
